;;伦敦西区桑德海姆剧院舞台上的“停止石油活动”活动人士。
;

;五人在“停止石油”抗议者扰乱伦敦西区桑德海姆剧院的《悲惨世界》演出后被捕。

;

;在歌曲《你听到人民唱歌吗？》的表演期间。 “停止石油”组织的成员举着横幅冲上舞台。在网上发布的一段抗议视频中，表演因一名成员高喊“停油”而暂停，观众一片嘘声。

;

;技术人员迅速上台，安全幕落下。接下来是主幕。根据 X（以前称为 Twitter）上的一篇帖子，四名抗议者随后将自己锁在舞台上。

;

;在 X 上的帖子中，该小组写道：“4 人被锁在舞台上”以法国大革命为主题的演出。冉阿让偷了面包来喂一个饥饿的孩子。多久之后我们就会被迫偷窃？”

; ;

;引用了 Just Stop Oil 的 Hannah Taylor 的话天空新闻称：“节目无法继续进行。我们正面临灾难。新的石油和天然气意味着农作物歉收、饥饿和死亡。这是对南半球的战争行为，也是对年轻人的彻底背叛。”

;

;德尔方特·麦金托什剧院 (Delfont Mackintosh Theatres) 首席执行官威廉·村 (William Village) 向 WhatsOnStage 证实，演出被停止，剧院也被疏散。抗议。演出门票将被退还。

;

;大都会警方表示：“10 月 4 日星期三 21 点左右，警方接到电话前往 WC1 沙夫茨伯里大道的一家剧院内举行抗议活动。当地官员很快赶到现场，并逮捕了五人。”

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 06:52:02 +0800 Floods linked to increased deaths from heart and lung disease, Australian-led research showshttps://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/oct/05/floods-linked-to-increased-deaths-from-heart-and-lung-disease-australian-led-research-shows
;;2023-10-04T22:30:06Z;
;
;;洪水
;

;人们早就知道洪水过后传染病的风险会增加但澳大利亚主导的一项新研究表明，灾难发生后三到六周，人们更有可能死于心脏病和肺病。

;

;这可能是由于以下原因导致获得医疗服务的机会减少：研究人员表示，道路封闭，以及接触黑霉菌和其他污染物（包括病原体）的机会增加。

;

;洪水占所有极端灾害事件的 43%，;预计严重程度、持续时间和频率都会增加; 由于全球变暖。

;
;
;

;所有死亡的死亡风险增加 2.1%，心血管死亡风险增加 2.6%，呼吸系统死亡风险增加 4.9%

;
;
;

;莫纳什大学的郭玉明教授是这项研究的共同领导者，他表示，胃肠道疾病等传染病的风险之前已经被检查过，但“我们想探讨其对心血管疾病和疾病的影响”。呼吸道疾病以及这种影响会持续多久”。

;

;研究人员研究了来自 34 个国家和地区（包括澳大利亚）的 761 个社区的数据，这些社区在 2000 年以来的十年中至少经历过一次洪水。总体死亡人数，重点关注 1110 万人心血管死亡和 490 万人呼吸道死亡。他们将这一数据与同一时期的洪水和温度数据进行了匹配。

;

;他们发现，即使在洪水消散之后，心血管死亡的死亡风险也有所增加，并且持续时间长达 50 天，呼吸道死亡的风险持续长达 60 天。周四在《英国医学杂志》上发表的这项研究发现，各种原因导致的死亡人数在洪水发生后 25 天达到峰值。

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;;;注册澳大利亚卫报的免费上午和下午电子邮件通讯，获取每日新闻摘要;;

    ;
    • ;
;

;在 35 个国家或地区中，受影响社区的洪水导致了 0.10% 的死亡、0.18% 的心血管死亡和 0.41% 的呼吸道死亡。这些洪水与死亡之间的关联因当地气候类型而异，并且在社会经济地位较低或 65 岁及以上人口比例较高的人群中更为明显。

;

;所有死亡的死亡风险增加了 2.1%，增加了 2.6%在 35 个国家或地区，心血管疾病死亡占 4.9%，呼吸道疾病死亡占 4.9%。

;

;“在澳大利亚，对呼吸系统健康的影响远高于对心血管疾病的影响，总的来说，我们处于所有疾病的中间位置。该大学公共卫生与预防医学学院的郭说，“在死亡人数方面，我们接受了调查国家的调查。”

;

;“澳大利亚的一个问题是，社会经济地位较低的地区的人们更容易受到洪水。”

;

;该研究没有探讨死亡的确切原因，但郭说，获得医疗服务的机会减少和接触污染物可能是其中的一个原因。

;

;“政府需要郭说：“我们应该在事件发生后数周内监测并保护人们的健康免受影响，而不仅仅是在事件发生后的几天内。”灾难解决方案表示：“需要进行进一步的研究来回答死亡率为何上升的问题，以便我们能够更好地制定预防策略。”

;

;除了郭提到的因素之外，汉纳说药物获取中断以及压力和悲伤可能会加剧现有的健康状况。

;

;“人们对心理生理途径知之甚少，但显然是真实的，”汉纳说。

;

;“清理受污染环境时增加的体育锻炼以及接触可能引发心脏病的刺激物也是一个可能的原因。其中许多将产生累积效应，最终使[人们]陷入困境。”南澳卫生局公共卫生医学顾问金伯利·汉弗莱博士表示，周四的研究“很重要”。

;

;周四的研究“很重要”。 >;

;

;;相关：;;在洪水之前，我认为气候变化不是我的问题。现在，我不再等待其他人来修复它 |艾拉·巴克兰;

;
;

;“它强调了洪水等极端天气事件对健康造成的持久而重大的影响，而这些事件与气候变化有着千丝万缕的联系。

;

;“它讲述了治疗遭受这些事件影响的患者的一线临床医生的第一手经验——我们知道，患者的健康不仅受到严重影响，而且在这些灾难发生后的几天、几周和几个月内都受到影响。”

;

;汉弗莱认为，如果不解决灾难的根本原因（化石燃料引起的气候变化），健康影响就会加剧，结果也会恶化。

;

;她说，缺乏准备和健康专业人员来管理影响。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 06:52:02 +0800 Giorgia Meloni turns to Rishi Sunak to take battle against migration beyond EUhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/04/giorgia-meloni-turns-to-rishi-sunak-to-take-battle-against-migration-beyond-eu
;;2023-10-04T21:30:05Z;
;
;;Giorgia Meloni 和 Rishi Sunak 在北约会议上。
;

;Giorgia Meloni 已转向英国首相里希·苏纳克（Rishi Sunak）开始反对欧盟以外的移民，这一点已经出现。

;

;在一些人所谓的西班牙框架中，首相们在一次历史性会议上迫使移民问题被提上议程。周四，50 名欧洲领导人在格拉纳达举行会议。

;

;在争夺德国荣誉称号的斗争中击败德国;欧盟成员国周三就移民问题达成了友好协议;，梅洛尼和苏纳克创造了另一个向难民发动战争的机会他们在更广泛的国际舞台上最喜欢的话题。

;

;参加欧洲政治共同体 (EPC) 峰会的领导人已经被分成了以扩大、国防、人工智能、能源安全和气候紧急情况为主题的小组。

;

;然而，在第11个小时，有消息称，在苏纳克未能说服EPC组织者西班牙将移民问题提上议程的消息公开后，梅洛尼联系了苏纳克。

;

;两位首相现在将主持一个有关该主题的单独小组，预计将提出欧盟和英国之间加强协调的必要性。

;

;苏纳克预计将宣布与比利时、保加利亚和塞尔维亚的新双边倡议加强情报共享和行动合作。

;
;

;;相关：;;意大利总理对德国为难民救援支付慈善费用感到“惊讶”;

;
;

;他在会议上表示：“欧洲大陆的非法移民数量达到近十年来的最高水平。成千上万的人在人口走私者的推动下死于海上，这种情况既不道德也不可持续。我们不能让犯罪团伙决定谁来到欧洲海岸。”

;

;EPC 是埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 的创意，但在幕后，领导人也对其未来的生存能力提出了质疑。

; < p>;EPC 背后的愿景是为欧盟内外领导人之间的非正式讨论创建一个平台，并将巴尔干国家、土耳其、亚美尼亚和阿塞拜疆坚定地纳入欧洲阵营。

;

;“领导人在宽敞的 El Palacio de Congresos 会议中心的白色皮沙发上进行的短暂会面才是真正的业务将进行的地方。

;

;阿塞拜疆和亚美尼亚之间能够促成和平谈判的希望破灭了由于欧洲对埃里温的支持，阿塞拜疆总统伊利哈姆·阿利耶夫拒绝了在西班牙与亚美尼亚总理尼科尔·帕希尼扬举行的欧洲会议。

;

;帕希尼扬后来表示，他仍会参加峰会，但表示两位领导人无法就有争议的卡拉巴赫地区签署一份“转折点文件”是“耻辱”。

;

;土耳其总理雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安是否会出席也不确定。

;

;截至周三晚间，由于科索沃和塞尔维亚之间持续的政治敌对，两国之间尚无进行斡旋谈判的计划。

;

;双方领导人将在格拉纳达进行最后一次会谈。不排除马克龙或德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨进行分钟干预，让他们进入同一个房间。

;

;扩大和俄罗斯战争仍将是所有讨论中的首要议题，特别是在最近美国因继续为乌克兰国防做出贡献而感到不安。

;

;欧盟的扩大也将成为周五上午欧盟领导人第二次会议议程上的主要议题。

;

; >;

;在过去 24 小时内，发现;可能需要至少 2500 亿欧元;来容纳所有等待加入欧盟的九个国家。

;

;一些国家已经支持欧盟内部改革的最后期限为 2027 年，并表示是否签署了预算模型到那时，容纳新国家会更容易。

;

;一些人认为新国家可以逐步加入，但包括欧盟首席外交官在内的其他人拒绝了这一观点，称唯一的成员国已满会员资格。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 05:52:01 +0800 Simone Biles magic leads USA to world gymnastics championships gold medalhttps://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/oct/04/simone-biles-leads-us-to-gymnastics-world-championship-gold-medal
;;2023-10-04T20:45:32Z;
;
;;西蒙·拜尔斯庆祝在安特卫普世界体操锦标赛上与美国队一起赢得金牌。
;

;在她被迫退出奥运会团体决赛并在场边度过余下的夜晚两年后，这一次西蒙·拜尔斯一直在那里直到最后。

;

;被指控阻止另一场比赛在喧闹的人群面前，拜尔斯在自由体操比赛中获得了金牌，但她连眼睛都不眨一下。她完成了一场灼热的表演，赢得了全场起立鼓掌，美国队以 167.729 的成绩在世界体操锦标赛上连续第六次夺得团体金牌。

;

;不过，这个夜晚也被定义为体操巨星背后的两场历史性表演。巴西队最终以​​ 165.530 分的成绩，以 165.530 分的成绩，夺得了历史性的团体银牌，兑现了她们这一代天才丽贝卡·安德拉德 (Rebeca Andrade) 和弗拉维亚·萨拉瓦 (Flávia Saraiva) 的功绩。德克萨斯州发挥了自己的潜力，带领法国队以 164.064 的成绩获得了他们的第一枚世锦赛铜牌。随着新国家的崛起，英国在安特卫普度过了一个艰难的夜晚，最终排名第六。

;

;尽管取得了胜利，但美国队一开始就运气不佳。在第一台器械的热身过程中，乔斯林·罗伯森在尝试难度极高的程跳马时落地笨拙，导致左脚受伤，被迫退出比赛。美国队深度实力如此之大，差别不大。

;

;不久之后，杰西卡·加迪洛娃就倒在了自己的程上。英国队在高低杠和平衡木上摔倒，连续第三届奖牌的前景变得越来越渺茫。

;

;当英国队苦苦挣扎时，巴西、法国、中国和意大利为奖牌而战直到最后。意大利队在高低杠上摔倒，巴西队取得了令人难以置信的好成绩，安德拉德凭借出色的自由体操和程跳马摘得银牌。与此同时，德热苏斯·多斯桑托斯展现出钢铁般的意志，以出色的高低杠动作夺得铜牌。

; ;

;当晚的结束与过去十年中的许多此类场合一样，拜尔斯摧毁了地板，获得了比赛的最高分并离开了当观众起立时，她登上领奖台。

;

;当她开始一系列可能具有历史意义的决赛时，拜尔斯目前在奥运会和世锦赛上获得了 33 枚奖牌，追平了维塔利·谢尔博 (Vitaly Scherbo) 的历史纪录保持者。没有哪位女性比拜尔斯赢得了更多的世界团体奖牌，她现已五次获得世界团体冠军。

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 02:52:01 +0800 South American monsoon heading towards ‘tipping point’ likely to cause Amazon diebackhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/04/south-american-monsoon-heading-towards-tipping-point-likely-to-cause-amazon-dieback
;;2023-10-04T18:00:01Z;
;
;;A tugboat and a ferry stranded on a sandbank formed by a severe drought hitting the rivers of the Amazon basin in the municipality of Iranduba, Brazil
;

;The South American monsoon, which determines the climate of much of the continent, is being pushed towards a “critical destabilisation point”, according to a study that links regional rainfall to Amazon deforestation and global heating.

;

;The authors of the report said they found their results “shocking” and urged policymakers to act with urgency to forestall a tipping point, which could result in up to 30% less rainfall, a dieback of the forest and a dire impact on food production.

;

;The study, ;published; on Wednesday in Science Advances, examines how forest degradation and monsoon circulation are interlinked.

;

;Using past observations and computer modelling, it finds that the Amazon and the South American monsoon are “one coupled system”, in which the evapotranspiration by the tropical rainforest recycles moisture from the Atlantic Ocean so that it can move south across the continent.

;

;Human degradation of the Amazon – by land clearance, fire, logging and mining – is pushing that system towards a tipping point, after which drier conditions would be expected to cause an abrupt “regime shift” in the rainforest, which would be unable to sustain itself and transport moisture.

;

;Other biomes in the region would also be affected, along with swathes of agricultural land because the monsoon stretches thousands of miles south from the Amazon to the River Plate (;Rio de la Plata;) basin. There would also be a climate impact because the Amazon – which would be worst affected – has historically served as an important carbon sink, though another study this week suggests ;it is now so degraded; that it is at best carbon neutral. A dieback of the forest would release enormous amounts of carbon.

;

;The researchers on the Amazon-monsoon paper saw several precursors of the tipping point, including falling rainfall in many areas, the steady lengthening of the Amazon dry season, reduced soil moisture and the increasing frequency and intensity of droughts. There have been three statistically one-in-100-year droughts in the space of a single decade.

;

;“It is shocking to see these signs of destabilisation,” said the lead author, Nils Bochow, of the University of Tromsø and the Potsdam Institute of Climate Impact Research. “But we shouldn't lose hope. We can still act. We need stricter rules regarding the rainforest.”

;

;Global heating is adding to the pressure on the forest. Not included in their paper because it is too recent is this year's fierce dry season, during which many Amazon rivers have fallen far below their average for this time of year, leading to navigation problems, water shortages and ;mass mortalities of dolphins and fish;.

;

;Previous studies have suggested a tipping point could be reached when 20% to 30% of the Amazon is cleared, though there is considerable uncertainty about exactly where the point might be. Currently, between 17% and 26% of the rainforest has been destroyed and at least that has been degraded.

;

;The paper does not give a prediction of when the tipping point might take place, though its authors say their findings confirm the risks and the likelihood that such a tipping point is much closer than other possible climate tipping points, such as the collapse of the Greenland ice sheet.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Mass death of Amazonian dolphins prompts fears for vulnerable species;

;
;

;Although deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon has halved since Brazil's centre-left president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, came to power at the start of the year, the forest continues to shrink. In Bolivia, the loss is accelerating.

;

;Niklas Boers, a professor of Earth system modelling at the Technical University of Munich and the Potsdam Institute, compared the Amazon-coupled monsoon system to a chair that is tilting further and further back to a point where even a breath of wind could knock it over.

;

;“My emotional response is anger,” Boers said. “With every square kilometre of deforestation, every fraction of degree of global warming, we are raising the risk of a tipping point. Yet, it is incredibly simple to just stop deforestation. It is an absolutely unique ecosystem that we really can't afford to lose.”

;

;Commenting on the paper, Dominick Spracklen, an Amazon expert and professor of environmental science at University of Leeds, said the study was worrying. “This rapid switch to a dry climate would have catastrophic implications for people living in Amazonia,” he wrote. “The study highlights the urgent need for people across Amazonia to work together to find ways to reduce deforestation, prevent further loss of forest and start to restore areas that have been lost in recent years.”

;Medics in the Gaza Strip have reported treating an influx of protesters who appear to have been deliberately targeted in the ankle in recent unrest at the volatile boundary of the blockaded Palestinian enclave.

;At least one person has been killed and dozens more wounded since demonstrations by groups of young men, some of them throwing stones and molotov cocktails, began in mid-September.

;

;The protests were ostensibly organised in response to an uptick in visits by Jewish groups to Jerusalem's sensitive al-Aqsa compound, ongoing Israel Defence Forces (IDF) raids targeting armed Palestinian cells in the occupied West Bank, and the economic misery caused by the Israeli-Egyptian siege of Gaza, now in its 16th year.

;

;An uneasy calm has returned to the strip, and border crossings for workers to enter Israel reopened on 29 September after mediation efforts by the UN, Egypt and Qatar. ;

;Seven people admitted to al-Awda hospital in the northern town of Beit Lahia are still receiving treatments for bullet wounds to the ankle, a joint that Dr Jean Pierre, a medical activity manager in Gaza for Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), said was extremely difficult to treat.

;

;“It's much harder to treat than any other part of the leg, because it is a joint that bears weight,” he said. “It involves a complicated graft called 'free flap' surgery, and it doesn't always mean the patient will be able to walk. If it fails, amputation is often necessary.

;

;“Only two doctors in Gaza can do it, and they do not have the microscopic equipment necessary to do intricate vascular repairs.”

; ;

;Human rights groups say that such targeting procedures are unlawful as they allow the use of potentially lethal force with no immediate threat to soldiers' lives.

;

;In a statement, the IDF said: “Over the past few weeks, the Hamas terror organisation has organised violent riots along the border fence, for purposes of harming Israeli security forces … It should be noted that the IDF resorts to live fire only after exhausting all available options, and only as necessary to handle imminent threat.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'A hidden universe of suffering': the Palestinian children sent to jail;

;
;

;The latest violence echoes the “Great March of Return” protests that began in 2018 and lasted nearly two years, in which 227 Palestinians were killed during weekly demonstrations at the separation fences. ;

;About 60% of the thousands of injured ;were hit in the legs; by sniper fire, according to the local health ministry – admissions that overwhelmed an already ;crumbling medical sector.;

;

;Since then, amputees using crutches have become a common sight on the enclave's streets. In response, MSF has funded a new prosthetics clinic for the strip's residents, and a limb reconstruction centre at al-Awda hospital.

;

;“It is sad to say we have become experts in this work,” said Rami Abu Jasser, one of the centre's supervisors. “We have much better facilities and equipment now than we did in 2018 and we can do most orthopaedic and plastic procedures. But we still cannot treat more than a handful of people a day.”

;

;One of the injured protesters, who gave his name as Khalid, had been shot through both ankles with one bullet. He was healing well, doctors said, but it would not be clear for months whether he would be able to walk again.

;

;“I was injured five times in the March of Return,” the 26-year-old said, pulling up his shorts to reveal scars around his knees. “In my thigh, in my hips, and I have shrapnel in my head.”

;

;Khalid was one of several hundred young men who took part in the recent clashes at the separation fence, at the behest of a newly formed group called “Rebel Youth”. Many people in Gaza, however, said that they believed Hamas was ultimately responsible for stoking the violence along the periphery. The latest round of protests do not seem to have significant public support.

;

;Since Hamas seized control of the 42-sq km (16-sq mile) strip, Israel has fought four wars and several smaller conflagrations against the area's rulers and its other active factions. These have proved devastating for the area's 2.3 million inhabitants. Gaza's residents also have next to no freedom of movement, and healthcare, electricity, sanitation and other crucial infrastructure have all but collapsed since Israel imposed the blockade.

;

;After the last major war in 2021, Israel has gradually increased work permits for people from Gaza for agricultural and construction work, an incentive for Hamas to keep quiet in order to alleviate the area's dire poverty and accompanying unrest. Gaza's unemployment rate has hovered at about 50% for years and more than half of the population lives below the poverty line.

;

;About 18,500 men are eligible to work in Israel, bringing about £2m into Gaza a day; many families and businesses keenly felt the 12-day border closure imposed after the protests began. Israel is now caught between a desire to show Hamas that there are financial consequences for fuelling the ;current wave of unrest; in the West Bank and the need to maintain calm on the Gaza front.

;

;Hamas last month announced that it would be cutting salaries of 50,000 civil servants, blaming a redirection of promised aid from Qatar. Talks with Doha on funding are ongoing.

;

;A recent International Monetary Fund report said that for any stable long-term economic recovery in Gaza, “lifting of the blockade and easing of the Israeli-imposed restrictions are essential”.
